name: Build the App
description: Time to put everything together! In this capstone project, you'll build a working Learning Journal app that combines Python, FastAPI, databases, and LLM integration. This project synthesizes all Phase 2 skills into a complete application.
short_description: Build a Learning Journal API with FastAPI, PostgreSQL, and AI-powered entry analysis using LLMs.

learning_steps.description: You'll build a Learning Journal API that allows users to create journal entries about their learning, stores them in a database, and uses an LLM to analyze entries for sentiment, extract topics, and generate summaries.

learning_steps.title: Dev Containers Tutorial
learning_steps.description: Before starting, learn about Dev Containers—a VS Code feature that creates consistent development environments using Docker. This ensures your project works the same way everywhere.

learning_steps.title: Journal Starter Repository
learning_steps.description: Start with this template repository that includes the Dev Container configuration, basic project structure, and dependency files. Fork it to your own GitHub account.

learning_steps.text: Open in Codespaces or VS Code
learning_steps.action: Open in Codespaces or VS Code:
learning_steps.description:
Option 1: Click 'Code' → 'Open with Codespaces' on GitHub (free tier available)
Option 2: Clone locally and open in VS Code with the Dev Containers extension

The Dev Container will automatically install Python, dependencies, and configure your environment.

learning_steps.code:
# Your API should have these routes:

POST /entries           # Create a new journal entry
GET  /entries           # List all entries (with pagination)
GET  /entries/{id}      # Get a specific entry
PUT  /entries/{id}      # Update an entry
DELETE /entries/{id}    # Delete an entry

POST /entries/{id}/analyze  # Analyze entry with LLM

learning_steps.description: Create a schema for storing journal entries:
learning_steps.code:
# Journal Entry should include:
- id: unique identifier (UUID or auto-increment)
- content: the journal text (required)
- created_at: timestamp
- updated_at: timestamp
- sentiment: string (populated by LLM analysis)
- topics: list/array of strings (populated by LLM)
- summary: string (populated by LLM)

learning_steps.description: Create an analysis function that sends journal entries to an LLM and stores the results:
learning_steps.code:
# Your analyze endpoint should:
1. Retrieve the journal entry from the database
2. Send it to the LLM with a well-crafted prompt
3. Parse the structured JSON response
4. Update the entry with sentiment, topics, summary
5. Return the analyzed entry

learning_steps.description: Configure your preferred LLM provider. Store credentials in environment variables, never in code.
Make your API robust with proper error handling:
learning_steps.code:
# Handle these scenarios:
- Entry not found → 404 response
- Invalid input → 422 with validation errors
- LLM API failure → 503 with retry message
- Database errors → 500 with safe error message

# Use FastAPI's exception handlers:
from fastapi import HTTPException
raise HTTPException(status_code=404, detail="Entry not found")

learning_steps.description: Use FastAPI's built-in docs at /docs to test all endpoints. Create several journal entries, analyze them, and verify the LLM responses are stored correctly.
learning_steps.code:
# Test checklist:
1. Create 3-5 test journal entries
2. Verify entries are persisted in database
3. Analyze each entry and check results
4. Test error cases (invalid ID, empty content)
5. Check pagination on list endpoint

learning_steps.description:
Update your README with:
• Project description and features
• How to run locally (with Dev Container)
• API endpoint documentation
• Environment variables needed
• Example API calls with curl or HTTPie
Push your completed project to GitHub! This becomes part of your portfolio. Consider sharing it on LinkedIn or the Learn to Cloud community Discord.

questions.prompt: Describe the architecture of your Journal API application and how the different components work together.
How did you implement the LLM analysis feature for journal entries, and what prompt engineering techniques did you use?

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you review my FastAPI code and check if I'm following best practices?
Can you help me debug why my LLM analysis isn't returning structured JSON?
Can you explain how to set up environment variables for my API keys?
Can you quiz me on REST API design principles?
Can you help me write better error handling for my endpoints?
Can you explain the difference between sync and async database calls in FastAPI?
Can you review my prompt engineering for the journal analysis feature?

checklist.text: Implemented all CRUD endpoints for entries
